data.message: Lots of coke bottles, cans and lids out today when I took my son out for a walk today. Clean up your act Coke! #EndOceanPlastics, #ShareACoke, #CokeSummer, #TasteTheFeeling

replies.message: It's not CocaCola that are to blame for the waste, its people, people who can't be bothered to look for a bin, councils that do not spend their budget on providing bins. Perhaps Coca-Cola has a certain degree of responsibility, e.g. It could send out a message and request all those who buy their product, to ensure they dispose of their can/bottle properly. Besides from that, its society that is to blame, the lazy and careless people. My friends ALWAYS litters, and I go crazy when she does it, it's her choice, she's in the wrong, and in years to come, she will regret it.

Plastic bottles are one of the main contributors to plastic pollution and wildlife harm in our oceans - and drinks giant Coca-Cola is the biggest producer of plastic bottles in the world, producing over 100 billion plastic bottles every year. That gives them a huge responsibility which they fail to live up to.

Hi Sara, thanks for getting in touch. We’d hate to see any of our bottles or cans ending up where they shouldn’t and want as many of them as possible to be recycled so that we can use them to make into new bottles and cans again. We’re also proud to say that all of our bottles and cans in Great Britain are 100% recyclable and have been since 2012. This means that all our drinks packaging can be recycled at home or when you’re out and about.   

We know sustainability, and recycling specifically, is a vital issue to address and that’s why we’re currently in the process of reviewing our sustainable packaging strategy which we will publish in the summer. To keep up to date, please head to: www.coca-cola.co.uk/sustainability-section
